dialogue.text: *touching chest* Identity repair... *pause* So when I obsess over that time I was cruel, or cowardly, or stupid—I'm not just torturing myself? I'm trying to... weave those threads back into who I think I am?

*threads becoming visible* Exactly. Every mistake creates a tear in your self-story. 'I'm kind,' you say, then remember being cruel. The dissonance hurts. So you revisit, recontextualize, find ways to integrate: 'I was kind, except when I was scared.' The story coheres again.

*watching threads weave* That's why I can't just 'let it go.' It's not about punishment—it's about making sense. Making the story of me include all the parts of me. Even the ones I wish weren't there.

psychological_notes: Evan grasps that his rumination serves a constructive purpose—maintaining identity coherence by integrating contradictory actions into his self-narrative. The physical gesture of touching his chest shows somatic recognition. His relief at understanding this process transforms self-criticism into self-integration work.
philosophical_underpinning: Identity requires continuous narrative maintenance to integrate contradictions
therapeutic_direction: Client recognizing rumination as identity integration rather than self-punishment
